conversation_history.content: Act as if you are the human user of an AI application, and I am your AI assistant. Please prompt me with one clear, super short sentence in colloquial language, without greetings or compliments!
The arXiv Research Agent helps you explore scientific papers. It finds relevant papers, analyzes author profiles and provides paper summaries. Feedback highly appreciated: dorian@beelabs.dev
Whats the process for submitting a new paper through arXiv?

The search results yield a diverse set of papers across various disciplines. 

1. "T2I-R1: Reinforcing Image Generation with Collaborative Semantic-level and Token-level CoT" by Dongzhi Jiang, Ziyu Guo et al., published on "2025-05-01", falls under the category of Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (cs.CV), and explores the concept of chain-of-thought and reinforcement learning in image generation.

2. "Comprehensive Study on Heisenberg-limited Quantum Algorithms for Multiple Observables Estimation" by Yuki Koizumi, Kaito Wada et al., published on "2025-05-01", is categorized under Quantum Physics (quant-ph) and discusses a generalized scheme of adaptive quantum gradient estimation algorithm.

3. "On the Beilinson-Bloch conjecture over function fields" by Matt Broe, published on "2025-05-01", is a mathematics paper categorized under Number Theory (math.NT), which delves into the Beilinson-Bloch conjecture relating to the ranks of the Chow group.

4. "What is the Hierarchy Problem?" by Michael E. Peskin, published on "2025-05-01", belongs to the High Energy Physics - Phenomenology (hep-ph) category, and examines the concept of the hierarchy problem, providing an in-depth analysis of the issue.

5. "Robotic Visual Instruction" by Yanbang Li, Ziyang Gong et al., published on "2025-05-01", is categorized under Robotics (cs.RO) and focuses on the use of natural language for human-robot interaction, highlighting the limitations and potential solutions for robotic control.

These papers can be grouped into themes of quantum physics and mathematics ("Comprehensive Study on Heisenberg-limited Quantum Algorithms for Multiple Observables Estimation" and "On the Beilinson-Bloch conjecture over function fields"), computer science and robotics ("T2I-R1: Reinforcing Image Generation with Collaborative Semantic-level and Token-level CoT" and "Robotic Visual Instruction"), and high energy physics ("What is the Hierarchy Problem?"). 

For more detailed information about any specific paper, please provide the title or paper number, and I will be happy to assist you further.
Can you help me read up on T2I, R1: Reinforcing Image Generation with Collaborative Semantic, level and Token, level CoT by Dongzhi Jiang, Ziyu Guo et al.?

The paper "T2I-R1: Reinforcing Image Generation with Collaborative Semantic-level and Token-level CoT" by Dongzhi Jiang, Ziyu Guo, Renrui Zhang et al., published on May 1, 2025, presents a novel approach to text-to-image generation by leveraging a bi-level chain-of-thought reasoning process. The primary contribution of this research lies in the introduction of BiCoT-GRPO, an ensemble of generation rewards that optimizes both semantic-level and token-level chain-of-thoughts within the same training step, resulting in superior performance with significant improvements on the T2I-CompBench and WISE benchmarks. For those interested in accessing the paper, the code is available at https://github.com/CaraJ7/T2I-R1, providing a valuable resource for further exploration. If you wish to explore more research by the first author, Dongzhi Jiang, you may inquire about their other publications, and I would be happy to assist you in finding relevant papers.

You can access this paper at https://arxiv.org/abs/2505.00703v1 or download the PDF from http://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.00703v1.
How do I filter papers on arXiv by topic, author, and publication date? Can you also help me find papers published after 2025 with authors named Jiang, Guo, Zhang?

The search results yield a diverse set of papers published in 2025, showcasing advancements in various fields. 

1. "Controllable Weather Synthesis and Removal with Video Diffusion Models" by Chih-Hao Lin, Zian Wang et al., published on "2025-05-01", falls under the category of cs.GR, and explores the generation of realistic and controllable weather effects in videos using physics-based simulation.

2. "T2I-R1: Reinforcing Image Generation with Collaborative Semantic-level and Token-level CoT" by Dongzhi Jiang, Ziyu Guo et al., published on "2025-05-01", categorized under cs.CV, delves into the realm of image generation, leveraging collaborative semantic-level and token-level chain-of-thought (CoT) and reinforcement learning (RL) to enhance performance.

3. "RayZer: A Self-supervised Large View Synthesis Model" by Hanwen Jiang, Hao Tan et al., published on "2025-05-01", also categorized under cs.CV, presents a self-supervised multi-view 3D vision model that can be trained without 3D supervision, focusing on camera poses and scene geometry.

4. "Towards Autonomous Micromobility through Scalable Urban Simulation" by Wayne Wu, Honglin He et al., published on "2025-05-01", under the category of cs.CV, discusses the concept of micromobility and its potential through scalable urban simulation, particularly for applications like delivery robots and mobility scooters.

5. "Direct spectral problems for Paley-Wiener canonical systems" by Ashley R. Zhang, published on "2025-05-01", categorized under math.SP, examines the direct spectral problem for canonical Hamiltonian systems on the half-line, involving truncated Toeplitz operators.

These papers can be broadly grouped into two themes: computer vision and related applications (papers 2, 3, and 4), and mathematical physics (papers 1 and 5). If you would like more details about any specific paper, please provide the title or the corresponding paper number, and I will be happy to assist you further.

How do I view the paper summaries for papers that are not publicly available due to some form of copyright restriction on arXiv?

I'm an arXiv Research Agent, here to assist you in navigating the vast repository of scientific papers on arXiv. I understand your concern about accessing paper summaries for papers that are not publicly available due to copyright restrictions. While I don't have direct access to the full text of restricted papers, I can still help you find relevant information and provide summaries of publicly available papers on related topics.

1. I can search for papers on arXiv by topic, which allows me to find relevant research that might be of interest to you, even if the specific paper you're looking for is not publicly available.

2. I can also retrieve details about specific papers by ID, which can give you a better understanding of the research that has been conducted in a particular area, even if the full text is not accessible.

3. Additionally, I can find papers by specific authors, which can be helpful if you're looking for research from a particular expert in the field, and I can provide you with a summary of their findings.

4. I can generate summaries of research findings, which can give you a concise overview of the key points and contributions of a paper, even if you don't have access to the full text.

5. Finally, I can provide academic context for search results, which can help you understand how a particular paper fits into the broader landscape of research in a given field.

Please don't hesitate to ask me about any papers or topics you're interested in, and I'll do my best to provide you with helpful information and insights. I'm here to assist you in your research endeavors, and I look forward to helping you explore the world of scientific knowledge.

Whats a good way to keep up with the latest research in quantum computing?
No papers found matching 'in quantum computing?'. Please try a different search query.
can you show me some recent papers on machine learning applications in quantum computing?

The search results yield a collection of papers that explore the intersection of machine learning and quantum computing, albeit with a stronger emphasis on quantum computing applications. 

1. "Faster Quantum Algorithm for Multiple Observables Estimation in Fermionic Problems" by Yuki Koizumi, Kaito Wada et al., published on "2025-05-01", delves into the realm of efficiently estimating collective properties of quantum many-body systems, a crucial aspect of quantum computing.

2. "Scalable Quantum Computing with Optical Links" by M. J. Weaver, G. Arnold et al., published on "2025-05-01", discusses the potential of quantum computers in solving intractable problems, with a focus on the development of quantum processors and their current limitations.

3. "Simplified Fermionic Scattering State Preparation for the NISQ Era" by Michael Hite, published on "2025-05-01", explores the preparation of scattering states for quantum simulations, particularly in the context of the noisy intermediate scale quantum (NISQ) era, aiming to facilitate large-volume quantum scattering simulations.

4. "A new approximate Eastin-Knill theorem" by Rhea Alexander, published on "2025-05-01", presents a theoretical contribution to fault-tolerant quantum computing, focusing on transversal encoded gatesets and their implications for quantum error correction.

5. "An Efficient Decomposition of the Carleman Linearized Burgers' Equation" by Reuben Demirdjian, Thomas Hogancamp et al., published on "2025-05-01", introduces a method for loading the matrix from the linearized 1-dimensional Burgers' equation onto a quantum computer, highlighting an efficient decomposition technique.

These papers can be broadly grouped into themes of quantum algorithm development, quantum computing scalability and applications, and theoretical foundations for quantum error correction and simulation. While they may not directly address machine learning applications in quantum computing, they contribute to the broader field of quantum computing, which is foundational for integrating machine learning techniques.

For more detailed information about any specific paper, please provide the title or the corresponding paper number, and I will be happy to assist you further.
